abstract.p: Humane Society of United States specialist Nancy Peterson letter on Apr 24 column urges companies that allow dogs at work to adopt policies to protect both other workers and dogs

block.p: Re ''Love Me, Love My Dog Goes Only So Far, Even in the Informality of the Dot-Com World'' (New Economy column, April 24):

The 9-to-5 routine may be stressful for many pets. If a company decides to allow dogs at work, it should have a pet policy that has specific rules regarding leashing, confinement, off-limit areas, cleanup, nuisance behavior and flea control.
Re ''Love Me, Love My Dog Goes Only So Far, Even in the Informality of the Dot-Com World'' (New Economy column, April 24):

The 9-to-5 routine may be stressful for many pets. If a company decides to allow dogs at work, it should have a pet policy that has specific rules regarding leashing, confinement, off-limit areas, cleanup, nuisance behavior and flea control.

Workplaces must be safe and healthful for pets and humans, and the needs of co-workers must be considered. But those employees ''already doing their best to get along with the other bipeds'' might discover that a furry paw or ear can relieve stress, combat depression and promote social interactions among workers.
The writer is an issues specialist on companion animals at the Humane Society of the United States.
